sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Alzheimer's disease - Dementia (Moderate to Severe): Memantine hydrochloride 28 mg/donepezil 10 mg ORALLY once daily in the evening
  • Alzheimer's disease - Dementia (Moderate to Severe): To switch to the fixed-dose, delayed-release combination of memantine hydrochloride 28 mg/donepezil hydrochloride 10 mg, begin on the evening following the last dose of individual components administered separately (memantine 10 mg twice daily or 28 mg extended-release once daily and donepezil hydrochloride 10 mg)

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: Safety and effectiveness have not been established.

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• Renal impairment, severe (CrCl 5 to 29 mL/min on Cockcroft-Gault equation): Switch to memantine hydrochloride 14 mg/donepezil hydrochloride 10 mg once daily if stabilized on memantine 5 mg twice daily or 14 mg extended-release once day and donepezil hydrochloride 10 mg.
  • Hepatic impairment, mild to moderate: No adjustment is necessary.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: -- Hypersensitivity to memantine hydrochloride, donepezil hydrochloride, piperidine derivatives, or any component of this product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Cardiovascular:
  • -- Vagotonic effects on the sinoatrial and atrioventricular nodes, including bradycardia or heart block, may occur
  • -- Syncope has been reported with use
  • Gastrointestinal:
  • -- Peptic ulcer disease and gastrointestinal bleeding may occur; close monitoring recommended, especially in those at an increased risk for developing ulcers
  • -- Diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting have been reported with use; close monitoring at treatment initiation recommended
  • -- Exaggeration of succinylcholine-type muscle relaxation during anesthesia is likely to occur
  • -- Neurologic:
  • -- Seizures may occur
  • Renal:
  • -- Bladder outflow obstruction may occur
  • -- Severe renal impairment; dosage reduction recommended
  • -- Genitourinary conditions that raise urine pH such as renal tubular acidosis or severe infection of the urinary tract may increase plasma levels of memantine hydrochloride
  • Respiratory:
  • -- Use caution in patients with a history of asthma or obstructive pulmonary disease

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (5% to 10%), Loss of appetite (8%), Vomiting (2% to 8%)
  • Hematologic:Ecchymosis (5%)
  • Immunologic:Infectious disease (11%)
  • Neurologic:Dizziness (2% to 5%), Headache (4% to 6%), Insomnia (5%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Heart block
  • Dermatologic:Stevens-Johnson syndrome
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (6%)
  • Neurologic:Syncope (2%)
  • Psychiatric:Suicidal thoughts

2.title: Class
2.mono:
• Central Nervous System Agent
  • Cholinesterase Inhibitor, Centrally Acting
  • N-Methyl-D-Aspartate Receptor Antagonist

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: The combination of memantine hydrochloride (an N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) antagonist that prevents glutamate from activating the NMDA receptors of the CNS) and donepezil hydrochloride (a reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that enhances cholinergic function and improves cognition) acts to improve the symptoms of Alzheimer's disease but does not prevent or slow the neurodegeneration of the disease..

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, donepezil, oral: 3 to 4 hours
  • Tmax, memantine extended-release, oral, multiple doses: 9 to 12 hours
  • Bioavailability, donepezil, oral: 100%
  • Effects of food, memantine/donepezil, Cmax and AUC, no effect; memantine Tmax, shorter

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono:
• Protein binding, donepezil, albumin 76%; alpha-1-acid glycoprotein 21%
  • Protein binding, memantine: 45%
  • Vd, donepezil: 12 to 16 L/kg
  • Vd, memantine: 9 to 11 L/kg

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Liver, donepezil via glucuronidation and CYP2D6 and CYP3A4 mediated metabolism.
  • Liver: memantine, partial metabolism
  • Metabolites, donepezil, 4 metabolites; 2 active: 6-O-desmethyl donepezil (active)
  • Metabolites, memantine: N-glucuronide conjugate, 6-hydroxy memantine, 1-nitroso-deaminated memantine: minimal activity
  • Donepezil, substrate of CYP3A4 and CYP2D6

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Renal clearance, memantine: involves active tubular secretion, which is controlled by pH dependent tubular reabsorption.
  • Renal, donepezil: 57%; 17% unchanged
  • Renal, memantine: 48% unchanged
  • Fecal, donepezil: 15%
  • Total body clearance, donepezil: 0.13 to 0.19 L/hr/kg

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • May be administered with or without food.
  • Capsule may be opened so that entire contents can be sprinkled on applesauce; swallow without chewing. Consume entire contents of capsule; do not divide dose.
  • Except when opened and sprinkled on applesauce, swallow capsule whole; do not divide, chew, or crush.

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• Improvement in signs and symptoms of Alzheimer-type dementia is indicative of efficacy
  • Symptoms of active or occult gastrointestinal bleeding, especially in patients with ulcer disease history or concomitant use of NSAIDs
  • Diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting at start of treatment

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
Namzaric
Oral Capsule, Delayed Release: (Donepezil Hydrochloride - Memantine Hydrochloride) 10 MG-14 MG, 10 MG-28 MG

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
• DONEPEZIL
    OVERDOSE: Data are limited. Based on its cholinergic effects, typical findings might include muscarinic actions consisting of: miosis, flushing, bradycardia, bronchospasm, increased bronchial secretions, involuntary urination and/or defecation, sweating, lacrimation, hypotension, and/or seizures. Because of its high degree of selectivity for AChE in the CNS and less peripheral selectivity, overdoses would be expected to exhibit more CNS-related symptomatology, including extrapyramidal effects. ADVERSE EFFECTS: Diarrhea, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, muscle cramps, insomnia, and fatigue.
  • MEMANTINE
    USES: Memantine is indicated in the treatment of moderate to severe dementia of the Alzheimer's type. PHARMACOLOGY: Memantine hydrochloride is a low to moderate affinity, noncompetitive N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor antagonist which binds to NMDA receptor-operated cation channels. Memantine also blocks the 5-hydroxytryptamine-3 receptor (at a potency similar to the NMDA receptor) and nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (at one-sixth to one-tenth the potency). However, memantine has low to negligible affinity for gamma-aminobutyric acid, benzodiazepine, dopamine, adrenergic, histamine, and glycine receptors and for voltage-dependent calcium, sodium, or potassium channels. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Overdose is rare. MILD TO MODERATE OVERDOSE: Effects can include agitation, bradycardia, confusion, dizziness, hypertension, lethargy, restlessness, unsteady gait, vertigo, vomiting and weakness. SEVERE OVERDOSE: Can cause nystagmus, hallucinations, psychosis, seizures, and coma. ADVERSE EFFECTS: The following adverse effects have been reported following therapeutic use of memantine (less than 6%): Headache, diarrhea, dizziness, somnolence, fatigue, muscle weakness, akathisia, agitation, increased motor activity, insomnia, tachycardia, bradycardia, hypertension, constipation, seizures, and psychosis.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
• DONEPEZIL
    • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
    • Decontamination: Consider activated charcoal if the patient is able to maintain airway or if airway is protected.
    • Atropine: Atropine sulfate is the drug of choice to treat muscarinic effects such as bradycardia, bronchorrhea, and bronchospasm. ADULTS - 1 to 2 mg IV repeated every 3 to 60 min as needed. CHILD - 0.05 milligram/kilogram up to 4 milligrams (usual dose 1 milligram),IM/IV every 10 to 30 minutes.
    • Bronchospasm: Albuterol, epinephrine
    • Seizure: IV benzodiazepines, barbiturates
    • Hypotensive episode: IV 0.9% NaCl 10 to 20 ml/kg, dopamine, norepinephrine, dobutamine. Consider central venous pressure or pulmonary artery monitoring.
    • Bradycardia: Atropine
    • Hemodialysis: Because of donepezil's large volume of distribution and high degree of protein binding (94% to 96%), hemodialysis is not expected to be of benefit.
    • Monitoring of patient: Monitor vital signs, ECG, fluid and electrolyte balance, especially with vomiting and diarrhea. Monitor and support respiratory and cardiovascular function.
  • MEMANTINE
    • Support: MANAGEMENT OF MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.. MANAGEMENT OF SEVERE TOXICITY: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. Treat severe agitation with small doses of benzodiazepines. Treat seizures with IV benzodiazepines; barbiturates or propofol may be needed if seizures persist or recur.
    • Decontamination: PREHOSPITAL: Prehospital gastrointestinal decontamination is not recommended because of the potential for CNS depression and subsequent aspiration. HOSPITAL: Administer activated charcoal if the overdose is recent, the patient is not vomiting, and is able to maintain airway.
    • Airway management: Ensure adequate ventilation and perform endotracheal intubation early in patients with significant CNS depression or repeated seizures.
    • Antidote: None.
    • Enhanced elimination procedure: Hemodialysis or hemoperfusion are unlikely to be useful because of the large volume of distribution of memantine. Plasmapheresis was used in one patient and was associated with a decrease in memantine concentrations but it is not clear that it affected patient outcome.
    • Monitoring of patient: Plasma concentrations are not readily available or clinically useful in the management of overdose. Monitor vital signs and mental status following significant overdose. ECG changes have been rarely reported with overdose. Obtain an ECG, and institute continuous cardiac monitoring.
    • Patient disposition: HOME CRITERIA: A patient with an inadvertent exposure, that remains asymptomatic can be managed at home. OBSERVATION CRITERIA: Patients with a deliberate overdose, and those who are symptomatic, need to be monitored for six hours to assess mental status. Patients should be observed for at least 12 hours after overdose of sustained release formulations. Patients that remain asymptomatic can be discharged. ADMISSION CRITERIA: Patients should be admitted for severe agitation, CNS depression or seizures. CONSULT CRITERIA: Consult a poison center or medical toxicologist for assistance in managing patients with severe toxicity or in whom the diagnosis is not clear.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
• DONEPEZIL
    TOXICITY: Overdoses of 45 mg and 50 mg resulted in nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea in two elderly adults, one of these patients developed persistent bradycardia (HR in the 40's); both had uneventful recoveries. THERAPEUTIC: ADULT dose is 5 to 10 mg orally once daily. CHILDREN: Safety and effectiveness not established.
  • MEMANTINE
    TOXICITY: A specific minimum toxic dose of memantine has not been delineated. A 35-year-old woman developed headache, dizziness, double vision, coma, tachycardia, hypertension, respiratory alkalosis, and seizures after ingesting 2000 mg of memantine. She recovered followed supportive care, including 6 cycles of plasmapheresis. An overdose ingestion of up to 400 mg of memantine resulted in restlessness, psychosis, visual hallucinations, somnolence, stupor, and coma. The patient recovered without permanent neurologic sequelae. One patient developed elevated serum uric acid, elevated serum alkaline phosphatase, and low platelet count after ingesting 112 mg of memantine extended-release daily for 31 days. THERAPEUTIC DOSES: ADULTS: IMMEDIATE-RELEASE: 5 to 20 mg orally once daily or in divided doses; MAX, 20 mg/day. EXTENDED-RELEASE: 7 to 28 mg orally daily; MAX, 28 mg/day. CHILDREN: The safety and efficacy of memantine in children have not been documented.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of gastrointestinal bleeding, especially with concomitant NSAID use
  • Side effects may include headache, diarrhea, dizziness, anorexia, vomiting, nausea, and ecchymosis.
  • Instruct patient to take once daily in the evening; capsules may be swallowed whole or opened, sprinkled on applesauce, and swallowed without chewing.
  • Warn patient/caregiver not to use any capsules that are damaged or show signs of tampering.
